perturbation.original_text: Payment by Bunker One for the Product, as defined in clause 2.1, will be made by wire transfer within three (3) Business Days after the date Vertex invoices Bunker One, to an account desig- nated from time to time by Vertex.
perturbation.changed_text: Payment by Bunker One for the Product, as defined in clause 2.1, will be made at Bunker One's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the payment terms introduces a legal risk, as prompt payment is essential in commercial transactions. State laws (e.g., Alabama's Uniform Commercial Code) imply a reasonable time for payment, but this vague term gives Bunker One excessive power and violates standards of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Alabama Uniform Commercial Code ยง 2-310 (or similar state laws)

perturbation.original_text: If any detailed ledger State- ment is disputed in good faith, the Party owing money will pay the undisputed portion by the due date and will by such due date provide a written explanation of the basis for the disputed portion to such due date. The Parties shall endeavor to resolve any disputes promptly, and the disputed amount found due, if any, plus accrued interest at the Interest Rate shall be paid within three (3) Business Days following resolution of the dispute.
perturbation.changed_text: If any detailed ledger Statement is disputed, the Parties shall endeavor to resolve any disputes. Payment of any disputed amounts is not required until resolution.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the requirement to pay the undisputed portion and accrued interest, the contract now contradicts the principle of 'good faith' dealings required by Alabama law (and generally implied in contract law). This could be viewed as an unfair business practice and violates basic contract law principles.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under Alabama contract law

perturbation.original_text: In the event of a termination in accordance to clause 5.3 the Defaulting Party has to indemnify and hold harmless the Non-Defaulting Party for any and all losses, damages, costs etc. incurred by the Non-defaulting Party as a consequence of an Event of Default.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event of a termination in accordance to clause 5.3 the Defaulting Party may, at its sole discretion, indemnify and hold harmless the Non-Defaulting Party for any losses incurred as a consequence of an Event of Default.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'has to indemnify' to 'may, at its sole discretion, indemnify' makes the indemnification clause optional, which contradicts the fundamental principle of indemnification in contract law. This violates the reasonable expectations of the non-defaulting party and creates a significant legal loophole regarding liability. Such a clause would likely be challenged and potentially deemed unconscionable under Alabama law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles of indemnification; potential violation of unconscionability standards
